item.title: 'He wouldn't be grateful if we did': Liberals hit out at Malcolm Turnbull's demands to explain the coup - The Sydney Morning Herald

'He wouldn't be grateful if we did': Liberals hit out at Malcolm Turnbull's demands to explain the coup  The Sydney Morning Herald

Malcolm Turnbull was removed as prime minister partly because his own tactics backfired and because MPs felt they would fare better at the looming election ...

item.title: Fighting back at last - The Australian
item.description:
Fighting back at last  The Australian

The Coalition entered the final parliamentary sitting week of the year divided, damaged and, to some extent, directionless. The defection of Victorian Liberal MP Julia Banks to the crossbench shattered morale last week. Disagreements over policy and political strategy looked set to cripple any prospect of Scott Morrison building momentum before the summer recess. A breakout in factional warring looked imminent. However, by yesterday there were early signs that Morrison was asserting his authority on the government. The Prime Minister also seemed more sure-footed when addressing the media an...

item.title: Five things you might not know about controversial backbencher Craig Kelly - ABC News
item.description:
Five things you might not know about controversial backbencher Craig Kelly  ABC News

By political reporter Jackson Gothe-Snape Craig Kelly is a three-term Liberal MP in the southern Sydney seat of Hughes. He was the most vocal critic of his party's energy policy and has threatened to sit on the crossbench. Who is this man and why was he worth saving? As the head of a local retailers' association, Mr Kelly won preselection for the seat of Hughes in 2010 after the retirement of Donna Vale. After growing the Liberals' winning margin in the seat in 2010, his first speech to Parliament described the challenges of raising a son with Down syndrome. "The special experience I have h...

item.title: NSW Liberal bosses step in to save Craig Kelly - ABC News
item.description:
NSW Liberal bosses step in to save Craig Kelly  ABC News

By political reporter Jane Norman The political career of an outspoken Liberal Party backbencher appears secured, with New South Wales party officials set to override the usual preselection process and endorse all sitting federal MPs. The ABC understands the NSW state executive will intervene in the preselection for all undecided seats where an incumbent was facing a challenge - something Prime Minister Scott Morrison has requested. This would ensure conservative Liberal MP Craig Kelly would not face a preselection battle, which he was widely expected to lose. It comes after an extraordinar...

item.title: This bitter fight sends one message to voters: the government only talks about itself - ABC News
item.description:
This bitter fight sends one message to voters: the government only talks about itself  ABC News

This time of the year is often referred to as the killing season, when politicians connive and scheme to overthrow their leaders to the bewilderment of ordinary voters. The killing season came prematurely this year, but the atmosphere inside Parliament House is just as febrile. The sense of anarchy and chaos is real in Canberra as the Morrison Government goes to war with itself — unable to put out political fires burning out of control and lurching from one crisis to another. The latest unedifying fight over whether to save outspoken conservative Liberal backbencher Craig Kelly is a proxy w...

item.title: Turnbull tells PM to call early election, says he had planned a poll for March - ABC News
item.description:
Turnbull tells PM to call early election, says he had planned a poll for March  ABC News

Former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull has infuriated his own backers by intervening in a Liberal Party preselection stoush and attempting to torpedo his replacement's solution. Key points: - Mr Turnbull said his comments regarding Mr Kelly's preselection were not part of a personal vendetta - The former PM suggested he thought Mr Kelly would not seek to topple the Government by sitting as an independent - Mr Kelly has been described as the "Member for Sky News rather than the Member for Hughes" by another Liberal MP Prime Minister Scott Morrison, who replaced Mr Turnbull as Liberal leader ...

item.title: SA Liberals fear new Killing Season - The Advertiser
item.description:
SA Liberals fear new Killing Season  The Advertiser

The Federal Government’s final sitting week of the year has been thrown into disarray following a public intervention from former Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull into the re-endorsement of NSW conservative MP Craig Kelly. Mr Turnbull also urged Scott Morrison to go to an early election and avoid the NSW Liberal government being punished by voters because of the federal turmoil gripping the party. The former prime minister has revealed he and Mr Morrison were planning to go to a March 2 election before he was overthrown in August. Mr Turnbull’s moves were quickly shut down with the Liberal P...

item.title: Parliament breastfeeding 'over the top': MP - The Australian
item.description:
Parliament breastfeeding 'over the top': MP  The Australian

Liberal backbencher Craig Kelly says female MPs breastfeeding in Parliament as 'over the top'.

item.title: 'Heated exchange' between Abbott and Laundy over Finkel energy plan - ABC News
item.description:
'Heated exchange' between Abbott and Laundy over Finkel energy plan  ABC News

Tensions between Liberal factional rivals Tony Abbott and Craig Laundy boiled over at the conclusion of Tuesday's party room meeting, in which dozens of Coalition backbenchers raised concerns about Alan Finkel's energy report. The special meeting was called to give Liberal and National MPs more time to debate the chief scientist's recommendations, including the introduction of a Clean Energy Target [CET] to encourage the development of low emission generators. While the three-hour meeting was described as "positive" and "constructive", the ABC has been told Mr Abbott and Mr Laundy had a "ve...

item.title: I won’t be silenced: Abbott - The Australian
item.description:
I won’t be silenced: Abbott  The Australian

The former prime minister, who is aggressively promoting an alternative conservative manifesto, yesterday asserted his right as a backbencher to speak out on policy matters as the Prime Minister chaired his last cabinet meeting before flying to Germany for a G20 ­summit. Since April, Mr Abbott has conducted a nationwide tour of marginal and conservative seats, visiting schools, RSL clubs and ­addressing branch meetings. “I am a member of the government and it has always been the Liberal Party tradition that backbenchers can speak their mind on policy issues,” Mr Abbott told the Manly Daily ...

item.title: Use secure Comcars, MPs told - The Australian
item.description:
Use secure Comcars, MPs told  The Australian

Despite this request, politicians yesterday told The Australian they were unlikely to increase their use of the government’s ­limousine service. In a circular this week, the Department of Finance advised MPs to use Comcars, reminding them on Wednesday they were more secure and “confidential”. “Comcar works extensively with security agencies to ensure its drivers deliver a secure car with driver service,” the circular said. “All Comcar drivers are ­security cleared and bound by the Australian Public Service Code of Conduct and Values, which ­ensures the highest levels of ­discretion, confide...

item.title: ‘People will die’ over renewables - The Australian
item.description:
‘People will die’ over renewables  The Australian

In comments branded “appalling” by Labor, NSW Liberal backbencher Craig Kelly has urged his government to scrap renewable energy targets or risk being responsible for an increase in deaths over winter. Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg has told his state counterparts at tomorrow’s COAG energy meeting that the clean energy target recommended by the Chief Scientist will not be on the agenda, because the Coalition has not yet reached agreement on the matter. “People will die,” Mr Kelly told ABC radio this morning. “We’ve seen reports only recently that one in four Australian households this wint...

item.title: Breastfeeding parliamentarians 'over the top', says Liberal backbencher - ABC News
item.description:
Breastfeeding parliamentarians 'over the top', says Liberal backbencher  ABC News

A Federal Government MP says women who breastfeed in Parliament are a "bit over the top" and are trying to make a "statement". Key points: - Liberal backbencher Craig Kelly rejects idea of introducing quotas to address female representation within the Coalition - Says former Greens senator Larissa Waters' breastfeeding her baby in Parliament was "a bit over the top" - Just 18 female Liberal parliamentarians across two houses of federal Parliament Liberal backbencher Craig Kelly used a Sky News interview to reject the idea of introducing quotas to address female representation within the Coa...

item.title: ‘States may have no choice on CET’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘States may have no choice on CET’  The Australian

The increased pressure from the federal Labor leader over gas comes as Energy and Environment Minister Josh Frydenberg calls on Victoria and the Northern Territory — both led by Labor governments — to lift moratoriums on gas development at a crucial Council of Australian Governments Energy Council meeting in Brisbane. “I don’t think there’ll be any change imminent between Liberal or Labor state governments in terms of fracking (but) in terms of natural gas exploration I think that’s a serious matter for states to consider,” the Opposition Leader said. The International Energy Agency has sla...

item.title: Clean energy target not dead - The Australian
item.description:
Clean energy target not dead  The Australian

Downplaying reports of angry Coalition MPs warning Malcolm Turnbull that his leadership will be on the line if he embraced a clean energy target that hits consumers with higher prices, Mr Frydenberg said yesterday’s partyroom discussion had offered the opportunity to update his colleagues on the findings of Chief Scientist Alan Finkel’s energy review. Mr Frydenberg said Dr Finkel had recommended that coal be kept in the system in order to keep power affordable and provide baseload power “What came through loud and clear from my colleagues last night is their deep concern, appropriately, abo...

item.title: GetUp accused of lying to inquiry - The Australian
item.description:
GetUp accused of lying to inquiry  The Australian

Hello and welcome to PoliticsNow, The Australian’s live blog on the happenings at Parliament House in Canberra. Scott Morrison prepares for his first G20 summit in Buenos Aires. But the Prime Minister’s crossbench troubles and questions over Malcolm Turnbull continue to dominate his life in Canberra. Richard Ferguson1.45pm:GetUp wants apology Left-wing group GetUp has called on a Liberal MP to apologise for claiming they provided false and misleading information into a parliamentary inquiry into the last federal election. Liberal MP for Tagney Ben Morton told the House of Representatives to...

item.title: $4.3bn clean loans fails coal gap - The Australian
item.description:
$4.3bn clean loans fails coal gap  The Australian

The government-owned green loans vehicle that Tony Abbott tried to abolish as prime minister has also failed to meet the benchmarked returns from its investments since March 2015, when the Coalition raised its targets and sparked criticism from the CEFC’s boss. The CEFC yesterday told The Australian it had committed more than $4.3bn for 79 projects since its inception, and so far ­had recouped about $870 million from repayments and loans being ­cancelled. In July, it revealed in a ­response to a question on notice from Senate estimates that the total capacity of all of its electricity gener...

item.title: Senior politicians rush to disclose free Foxtel subscriptions amid uncertainty - ABC News
item.description:
Senior politicians rush to disclose free Foxtel subscriptions amid uncertainty  ABC News

Some of Australia's most senior politicians have been caught out not declaring a free pay television subscription worth up to $1,600 a year. Key points: - Pay TV lobby group ASTRA offers the freebie - Morrison, Sinodinos, Albanese, Hinch and Bandt update register of interests - There is confusion about whether politicians need to declare the gift Treasurer Scott Morrison and Industry Minister Arthur Sinodinos have rushed to update their register of interests after being contacted by the ABC. Labor MPs Anthony Albanese and Tim Watts, crossbench senator Derryn Hinch, and Greens MP Adam Bandt ...

item.title: Government's latest plebiscite attempt expected to be blocked by Senate - ABC News
item.description:
Government's latest plebiscite attempt expected to be blocked by Senate  ABC News

The Senate is expected to reject the Federal Government's second attempt at holding a same-sex marriage plebiscite, clearing the way for a postal vote by the end of the year. After a two-hour partyroom debate, Liberal MPs voted overwhelmingly in favour of maintaining the party's policy, defeating a push by some backbenchers for a free vote in Parliament. Only seven Liberals voted in favour of change: Warren Entsch and Trevor Evans (Qld); Tim Wilson and Jason Wood (Vic); John Alexander and Trent Zimmerman (NSW); and Senator Dean Smith (WA). In a bid to quell the internal unrest while honouri...

item.title: Trump's climate science sceptic environment chief to visit Australia - ABC News
item.description:
Trump's climate science sceptic environment chief to visit Australia  ABC News

A climate science critic and one of the most controversial figures in the Trump administration will soon tour Australia in a visit environmental activists are likely to target with protests. Key points: - Critics accuse Pruitt of trying to weaken the EPA - Liberal backbencher Craig Kelly says Australia should welcome Pruitt "with open arms" - Greenpeace says visit could spark protests and is not helpful for Australia as it tackles climate change policy Lawyer Scott Pruitt was last year handpicked by Donald Trump to head the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Critics accuse the former...

item.title: Abbott claims victory on CET - The Australian
item.description:
Abbott claims victory on CET  The Australian

Declaring the backbench would “end up saving the government from itself”, Mr Abbott said the Coalition was “getting the message that we just have to drop any idea of a clean energy target over and above the existing Renewable Energy Target” — which he legislated as prime minister in 2015. “We have more than enough renewables in the system already and if there were to be an attempt to legislatively increase subsidies for renewables, I couldn’t and won’t support it,” he told Sydney’s 2GB radio. yesterday. “I’m encouraged that the Prime Minister is talking almost as much about coal, baseload a...

item.title: Voter split over MP expulsions - The Australian
item.description:
Voter split over MP expulsions  The Australian

Voters are dividing along party lines on whether to disqualify MPs who hold dual citizenship amid a growing political fight over Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce and six senators who could be expelled from parliament for breaching the Constitution. A special Newspoll, conducted exclusively for The Australian, finds that 44 per cent of voters agree that politicians should be disqualified if they are entitled to the citizenship of a foreign country, but 43 per cent disagree and 13 per cent are uncommitted. With dozens of MPs facing questions over their status, Liberal MP Craig Kelly declar...

item.title: How changing the Liberal leadership inadvertently changed the asylum-seeker debate - ABC News
item.description:
How changing the Liberal leadership inadvertently changed the asylum-seeker debate  ABC News

By political reporters Melissa Clarke and Brett Worthington Few could have predicted that the demise of Malcolm Turnbull, the man conservatives in his own party had long denounced as being too moderate, would prompt the likely removal of all asylum-seeker children from Nauru. It's not that Mr Turnbull's removal from the prime ministership brought with it an end to the Federal Government's stance on asylum seekers. But it did create a political vacuum that ultimately changed the political landscape and fate of these children. This debate isn't new, so why is it changing now? Campaigners, the...

item.title: ‘A few facts’: Turnbull, Morrison in public spat - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘A few facts’: Turnbull, Morrison in public spat  The Advertiser

The flashpoint was Mr Turnbull’s appearance on Australia’s behalf at a climate change summit in Bali this week, where he met President Joko Widodo. Mr Turnbull noted Indonesia had “serious concern” about Mr Morrison’s decision to consider moving Australia’s embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, but he believed a trade deal with the country would still go ahead. “There is no question, were that move to occur, it would be met with a very negative reaction in Indonesia. This is, after all, the largest Muslim-majority country in the world,” he said. It seems Mr Morrison did not apprecia...

item.title: National security fears over Chinese gas pipelines deal could be eased through investment: Liberal MP - ABC News
item.description:
National security fears over Chinese gas pipelines deal could be eased through investment: Liberal MP  ABC News

By political reporter Matthew Doran A Federal Liberal MP has suggested a Chinese and Hong Kong based consortium hoping to buy large swathes of the nation's gas pipelines could allay national security concerns by committing to invest in the sector, as security analysts urge the government to block the deal. The Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) is considering the CK consortium's $13 billion bid for APA Group, which owns tens of thousand of kilometres of pipelines, gas mains, storage facilities and processing plants across the country. The company already has significant financial intere...

item.title: Taylor plan prolongs coal’s power - The Australian
item.description:
Taylor plan prolongs coal’s power  The Australian

Newly appointed federal Energy Minister Angus Taylor will consider a plan to upgrade the ­efficiency of Australian coal-fired power stations to improve performance, cut emissions and prolong their operating lives, among a suite of options to shore up the ­national power supply. As the minister plots a course to boost the supply and reliability of Australia’s baseload power, sources say the government will run the rule over a package offering support to help companies upgrade or expand existing power stations. Mr Taylor declined to confirm or deny which approach was likely to form a central ...

item.title: Opinion: Why conservative voters fail to see gender as an obstacle to political success - ABC News
item.description:
Opinion: Why conservative voters fail to see gender as an obstacle to political success  ABC News

By Andrea Carson When Julie Bishop called out that it was "not acceptable" for her party to add to Australia's political gender gap, it marked a watershed moment for conservative politics. Her speech at a Women's Weekly forum last week marked the first time Ms Bishop, a party heavyweight, had publicly acknowledged the party's role in the under-representation of women in Australian politics. Women make up 50.7 per cent of the Australian population, yet just under a third of the Federal Parliament. About one in five federal Coalition MPs is female. Ms Bishop's comments followed a string of Li...

item.title: Analysis: Heckled after miscarriage scare: Bullying of women isn't just confined to Federal Parliament - ABC News
item.description:
Analysis: Heckled after miscarriage scare: Bullying of women isn't just confined to Federal Parliament  ABC News

By Jessica Strutt As the list of federal female politicians who have either experienced or witnessed bullying and intimidation in the workplace continued to grow this week, a key question remained — is there any genuine appetite to tackle the problem? The claims have no doubt only further dissuaded more women from entering politics — a blow to a group already grossly underrepresented in parliaments at both a state and federal level. The debate about the treatment of female MPs was sparked when federal Liberal MP Julia Banks announced she would not contest the next election after suffering "...

item.title: Liberal MP announces she won't contest next election, says spill was 'last straw' - ABC News
item.description:
Liberal MP announces she won't contest next election, says spill was 'last straw'  ABC News

Liberal MP Julia Banks has announced she will not contest the next election after "bullying and intimidation". Key points: - Julia Banks was the only Liberal MP to win a seat from Labor at the last election - She says she won't contest next election because of bullying and intimidation both within the Liberal Party and from the Opposition - She wanted Malcolm Turnbull to remain PM and says the Liberal leadership spill was "the last straw" She said last week's Liberal leadership spill was the "last straw", and argued she would always put Australia's national interests before internal politic...

item.title: Confused about the PM's leadership crisis? Here's how we got here - ABC News
item.description:
Confused about the PM's leadership crisis? Here's how we got here  ABC News

By political reporter Jackson Gothe-Snape Less than a week after securing his party's support for a new energy policy, Malcolm Turnbull's leadership has been challenged. Here is what you need to know about how we got here. The Prime Minister has beaten Peter Dutton 48-35 in a Liberal party room leadership spill. Mr Turnbull resigned as leader at the start of the meeting to prompt a vote to test the support of his opponent. Mr Dutton has now resigned from Cabinet, giving him greater freedom to campaign for the leadership in coming days and weeks. Mr Turnbull will need to reshuffle his frontb...

item.title: Turnbull's backdown on energy fails to appease Coalition detractors - ABC News
item.description:
Turnbull's backdown on energy fails to appease Coalition detractors  ABC News

The Prime Minister's backdown on energy policy has not placated some rebels in the Coalition party room who continue to criticise government policy and threaten to cross the floor. Key points: - Turnbull will propose to set energy targets by regulation - Some Nationals MPs concerned Opposition will increase target if they win office - Dutton plays down reports he would challenge Turnbull The fraught debate within the Coalition has fuelled speculation about a possible leadership challenge, but Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton today declared his support for Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull a...

item.title: Malcolm Turnbull dumps plan to legislate Paris emissions targets - ABC News
item.description:
Malcolm Turnbull dumps plan to legislate Paris emissions targets  ABC News

Malcolm Turnbull has capitulated to rebels in the Coalition party room, dumping a plan to embed emissions reduction targets in Commonwealth legislation. Key points: - Turnbull weakened stance on emissions targets to appease rebel MPs - The 2016 Paris Agreement set emissions targets of 26 to 28 per cent lower by 2030 - Cabinet ministers to meet on Sunday to discuss new approach to energy policy To appease critics and lessen the prospect of a backbench revolt, the Prime Minister will instead propose setting emissions targets by regulation, which does not need the assent of Parliament. The rec...

item.title: The climate wars aren't over, but Labor holds the trump card - ABC News
item.description:
The climate wars aren't over, but Labor holds the trump card  ABC News

By Laura Tingle It would easy to simply see the current stand off over energy and climate change policy as what the late and legendary rugby league commentator Rex Mossop would have called "deja vu all over again". At one end of the spectrum, the Greens reject the government proposal for a set of policy levers, which potentially put the climate wars of the last decade to bed. You will recall that in 2009 the Greens insisted that the Rudd government's emissions reduction plans were not ambitious enough, giving Labor no option but to negotiate with the Coalition, then led by Malcolm Turnbull....

item.title: Liberal MP says he's sorry for MH17 remarks but insists they were taken out of context - ABC News
item.description:
Liberal MP says he's sorry for MH17 remarks but insists they were taken out of context  ABC News

Liberal backbencher Craig Kelly has apologised to the families of Australians who died when MH17 was shot down after saying Russia's role in the crime should be "looked over." Mr Kelly told Sky News yesterday there was not much to gain from world leaders putting pressure on Russia for its role in bringing down the plane. He made the comments after father Anthony Maslin, whose three children were killed on the flight, criticised US President Donald Trump's meeting with Russia's President Vladimir Putin. External Link: Anthony Maslin Facebook post Mr Kelly's suggestion angered the families of...

item.title: Federal Liberal Craig Kelly could quit the party if he loses pre-selection - ABC News
item.description:
Federal Liberal Craig Kelly could quit the party if he loses pre-selection  ABC News

Federal Liberal MP Craig Kelly is threatening to quit the Government and put the Coalition's slim Parliamentary majority at risk, if he loses his preselection fight in New South Wales. Key points: - Two Liberals challenging Craig Kelly for pre-selection - Mr Kelly has threatened to go to the crossbench if he loses party pre-selection - Sources say it is is a factional stoush and he is being targeted by moderate Liberals because he is a conservative Nominations for preselection closed last Friday and the ABC understands two candidates are challenging Mr Kelly for his Sydney seat of Hughes — ...

item.title: Analysis: Nationals go feral on their Liberal colleagues to secure banking royal commission - ABC News
item.description:
Analysis: Nationals go feral on their Liberal colleagues to secure banking royal commission  ABC News

On the afternoon of September 13, in Committee Room 1R2 at Parliament House in Canberra, a Powerpoint presentation was firing up. Renegade Nationals MP George Christensen had invited a small group of his Coalition colleagues for a special presentation on the banks. Among those in attendance, fellow backbenchers Llew O'Brien, Damian Drum, Ann Sudmalis and Craig Kelly. There was also a representative for both Ken O'Dowd and then-deputy PM Barnaby Joyce in the room. Over the course of an hour or so, the politicians were methodically taken through a short history of banking behaviour since the ...

item.title: Liberal MP John Alexander checking possible dual citizenship - ABC News
item.description:
Liberal MP John Alexander checking possible dual citizenship  ABC News

Liberal backbencher John Alexander is making urgent enquiries to determine whether he is a British citizen by descent. The Sydney-based MP's father was born in the United Kingdom, but Mr Alexander believes he renounced his citizenship after he migrated to Australia. Mr Alexander has contacted British authorities for confirmation. The ABC understand Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, who announced a new citizenship disclosure process earlier today, was told about Mr Alexander's situation this afternoon. Mr Turnbull said he received advice from the federal director of the Liberal Party, Andrew ...

item.title: Coalition signs off on new energy plan to replace Clean Energy Target - ABC News
item.description:
Coalition signs off on new energy plan to replace Clean Energy Target  ABC News

A meeting of the Coalition party room has agreed to ditch the Clean Energy Target (CET). Key points: - The party room agreed to ditch the CET and instead adopt a National Energy Guarantee - That NEG would require electricity retailers to have a minimum amount of power constantly available - Malcolm Turnbull and Josh Frydenberg will provide more detail on the new plan at 1:15pm MPs today signed off on a new plan including a National Energy Guarantee (NEG), which Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull argues will make power bills cheaper and more reliable while still cutting down carbon emissions. T...
